title: 111_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Evidence Request Efficiency Act of 2009" and includes improvements to Title 18. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to change procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations. The procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations under Title 18 of the United States Code are amended to specify issuance by a court of competent jurisdiction. The procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations under Title 18 of the United States Code are amended to specify issuance by a court of competent jurisdiction. This includes State court warrants issued using State warrant procedures. The procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations under Title 18 of the United States Code are amended to specify issuance by a court of competent jurisdiction, including State court warrants. The procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations under Title 18 of the United States Code are amended to specify issuance by a court of competent jurisdiction, including State court warrants. Any district court or United States court of appeals with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated, located where the provider of a communication service is based, or acting on a foreign request. The procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations under Title 18 of the United States Code are amended to specify issuance by a court of competent jurisdiction, including State court warrants. The provider of a communication service is located where the wire or electronic communications, records, or information are stored, or acting on a foreign request. The procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations under Title 18 of the United States Code are amended to specify issuance by a court of competent jurisdiction, including State court warrants. The court must have jurisdiction over the offense being investigated and be in or for a district where the provider of a wire or electronic communication service is located. The procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations under Title 18 of the United States Code are amended to specify issuance by a court of competent jurisdiction, including State court warrants. The court must have jurisdiction over the offense being investigated and be in or for a district where the provider of a wire or electronic communication service is located, a landlord, custodian, or other person subject to certain sections, or acting on a request for foreign assistance. The procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations under Title 18 of the United States Code are amended to specify issuance by a court of competent jurisdiction, including State court warrants. The court must have jurisdiction over the offense being investigated and be in or for a district where the provider of a wire or electronic communication service is located, a landlord, custodian, or other person subject to certain sections, or acting on a request for foreign assistance pursuant to section 3512 of this title. The procedures for court-issued warrants in investigations under Title 18 of the United States Code are amended to specify issuance by a court of competent jurisdiction, including State court warrants. A Federal judge may issue orders to execute foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions. A Federal judge may issue orders to execute foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions, including search warrants and warrants for contents of stored information. A Federal judge may issue orders for forfeiture, sentencing, and restitution, which may include search warrants, warrants for stored electronic communications, and orders for pen registers or trap and trace devices. The Federal judge may issue orders for forfeiture, sentencing, and restitution, including search warrants, warrants for stored electronic communications, pen registers, trap and trace devices, and orders for testimony or document production. The Federal judge may appoint a person to direct the taking of testimony, statements, or production of documents in response to a request from a foreign authority. In response to a request from a foreign authority, a Federal judge may appoint a person to direct the taking of testimony, statements, or production of documents. The appointed person has the authority to issue orders for appearance, production of documents, administer oaths, and more. The appointed person under a Federal judge's order can issue orders for appearance, production of documents, administer oaths, and take testimony or statements. An application for execution of a request from a foreign authority may be filed in the relevant district. The appointed person under a Federal judge's order can issue orders for appearance, production of documents, administer oaths, and take testimony or statements. An application for execution of a request from a foreign authority may be filed in the relevant district where the person resides or where the documents are located. The appointed person under a Federal judge's order can issue orders for appearance, production of documents, administer oaths, and take testimony or statements. Requests for appearance or production of documents can be made in the district where the person resides, where the documents are located, in a district where related Federal criminal investigation is ongoing, or in the District of Columbia. The search warrant limitation under a Federal judge's order requires the application to be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. The search warrant standard allows a Federal judge to issue a search warrant. A search warrant from a foreign authority must be filed in the district where the search is to take place. A Federal judge can issue a search warrant only if the foreign offense would be punishable by imprisonment for more than one year in the United States. A search warrant from a foreign authority can be issued in the United States if the foreign offense would be punishable by imprisonment for more than one year. The warrant can be served anywhere in the United States, and foreign authorities or interested parties can also seek assistance under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code for criminal investigations or prosecutions. An order or warrant issued under subsection (d) can be served anywhere in the United States. Foreign authorities or interested parties can seek assistance for criminal investigations or prosecutions under section 1782 of title 28, United States Code. Definitions for 'Federal judge' and 'attorney for the Government' are provided in this section. The section defines 'Federal judge' and 'attorney for the Government' as per the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. 'Foreign authority' refers to foreign judicial or investigative bodies involved in criminal proceedings. The term 'foreign authority' is defined as a foreign judicial authority or investigative body involved in criminal proceedings. Foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions.
